question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. A better understanding of cinema as an entity through time since its conception
2. A stronger sense of what matters to filmmakers at various points in time and how that manifests in their work
3. How to analyze the less obvious elements of film in pursuit of the author's purpose

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read film theory papers and understand them in regard to their historical background. I also learned how film theorist engage with one another over the years and changed ideologies with the advent of new technologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about major film theorists and their theories, including bell hooks, Bazin, Siegfried Kracauer and Erwin Panofsky. I learned how to write a paper about theory and I learned how to write and analyze films through various theoretical lenses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Overall, I gained a new understanding for how film theory has emerged and changed over time. Before, I knew film theory only from bits and pieces that I had read (out of context) in other courses, but this course really helped to frame and contextualize theory as a whole. I most enjoyed the semiotics unit and how investigating cinema as a language influenced more modern theorists in thinking about the socio-political impacts of film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned some historical background on cinema and early film, as well as more applied techniques like understanding film production/construction of shots/the effect they have and how to critically evaluate the position a film might have relative to its social/political context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: From classical film theory to modern and contemporary film theory. Learned how to read theories and analyze films with the theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history and ideologies surrounding specific figures who have contributed to the development of film theory. I feel that my understanding of realism and identity as it relates to cinema strengthened after contextualizing films with in-class lectures. Finally, I had the opportunity to expand upon and adapt a paper to fit new criteria. I appreciated the space to rework and build a paper after the feedback stage as I often abandon papers once they are submitted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Film analysis, how to understand theoretical readings, and how to apply those readings to films.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have never taken a film class, so considering it was my first time, my ways of thinking was much different than what I was used to. I learned how to watch films and analyze them critically, understand how film theory is applicable to real world, and read interesting works from important film theorists.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed having occasional in person screenings. While I watched each of the assigned films, I felt that my attention outside of the classroom was more vulnerable to distractions. I also feel that the class was well-suited for lectures but would appreciate if the slides were more engaging and easier to dissect. Some of the text heavy slides were difficult to piece through and would have been more beneficial as handouts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the theories themselves to be incredibly intellectually stimulating. The course readings were all so fascinating, and while challenging, definitely made me think on a deeper level about the construction and purpose of film.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The theories are very interesting and enlightening to learn. They cover contents from the classical theories to modern and contemporary ones, which was helpful to know how the film theory developed and the shifts of focus of the film theorists over time. The professor also provided many contexts that made the theories make more sense. The films we watched were all really great and the professor was good at guiding us on how to analyze films shot to shot and connected them with the theories. So I really learned a lot about how to watch a film critically.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I feel that either making the class entirely lecture-based or cultivating an environment that inspires participation would enhance intellectual simulation. Because the readings were dense, I feel that assigning smaller sections would increase students engagement and understanding with them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're at all interested in the ways people think about, question, and scientifically analyze cinema, this course is a great introduction into film theory. Through comprehensive and thorough lectures, you will gain a better understanding of the ways in which cultural, historical, and political contexts have shaped why people make films and how they understand the films they have made.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this media theory course, I gained a deep understanding of media's evolution, from foundational debates about writing and mediation to contemporary digital culture. The course equipped me with critical frameworks to analyze how different media forms - from print to digital platforms - shape human experience and social relationships. Key theoretical concepts like technological determinism, cultural techniques, and media archaeology enhanced my ability to examine the complex interplay between media, technology, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a new perspective on what the "media" term media can mean, gained new frameworks to understanding how society and media interact, and gained meaningful insight into how I personally interact with media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has given me a whole new understanding of the concept of media. Because before I chose this major, I knew almost nothing about media. In this class, I learned a lot about the concept of media and the historical process of media. In particular, I am deeply impressed by McLuhan's theory. He taught me that media can influence our perception and shape our society. And I also realized commodification and entertainment, it makes me know that we need to keep our own judgment in the market to find the real value

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The content in the class is really interesting and I liked the group discussions. However, this is not an "easy A" class because the TAs do all of the grading. The TAs grade super harshly and make it really hard to know how to do better in the future, which was really frustrating. Even after asking for feedback and support, they did not help us improve our grades. Also, a huge part of this grade is participation (literally speaking once per every class despite it being a large class) and the final project, which made us really nervous.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to view art differently, as well as the role I play as a spectator in art. It changed my view of art as in the one trapped in a frame and helped me realize how diverse and incredibly powerful art is. It also pushed my understanding of art as a political force, revealing how unique ideas can have great impacts on policy change and societal expectations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

The course consistently challenged us to write scripts on subjects we had no personal experience with or prior knowledge of. With a weekly writing assignment, I learned to draft quickly and then focus on revisions rather than getting bogged down by details in the initial draft.Lastly, I cultivated the ability to provide constructive feedback to my peers in class. Engaging in script readings and discussions allowed me to refine my communication and comprehension skills while collaborating effectively with my classmates.

response_text: This course is very cool. You actually learn how to write a screenplay. You start slow and small, with 5- to 10-page short films, and Prof. Bell walks you through the process, so it's not scary. You also read your screenplay in class, and everybody gives feedback. It's vulnerable, but so constructive. You learn so much from your peers in this course. By the end of it, writing an 80-page script is time-consuming, but not super challenging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Although it was stressful at times, I appreciated the weekly 10-page requirement because it truly pushed me to write, which, in my opinion, is the hardest part. I also liked the reading and casting in class component, which helped me gain confidence and improved my work progress. Watching and later analyzing the movies was also a lot of fun, and I learned a lot from reading scripts while watching them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learnt a lot in this class, and it had solidified my decision to go into making documentaries professionally.1. I've learnt to be more analytical in my interaction with documentaries as an audience member. I've learnt to not just share initial thoughts but deeply analyse editing techniques, politics, specific frames and angles and how all these come together to tell a compelling story.2. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, from reflections accompanying the different Engage and Mini-Engage assignments and the many free-writes we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class, more than any other class I've taken this semester.3. I've gotten better at intimate interviews, audio documentation and editing and even video documentation and editing. One thing I enjoyed about the class was the Engage Assignments. They made the theory we were learning in class more practical. I'm far from an expert, but this class has provided a strong foundation!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the mechanism behind cameras and how light works to produce images. I learned to use and shoot with a film camera, including the technical and aesthetic aspects of black and white photography. Developed an eye for light, composition and emotional content to drive artistic and documentary storytelling. Learned darkroom techniques such as film processing, printing, burning and dodging and scanning. Discussion of black-and-white photography in seminar setting as well as notable works by photographers in the past and present.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

developing black&white photographs

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course provided a great basis for learning how to take black and white photos, and specifically film. We learned about the various components of an image such as emotional context and light and how to use a camera (i.e., ISO, shutter speed, and aperture).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned darkroom practices of processing and developing film. I expanded my knowledge of photography and what makes a strong image. I learned how to better shoot black and white.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely developed a much more well rounded set of darkroom skills and it was great to be forced to shoot black and white which was always something that I never did too much of. I've definitely looked at prints in a new light knowing all the things that I could do to it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a lot of technical skills in this course, including how to work a film camera, load film, develop film, and print in the darkroom. We also practice talking about our own work and the work of others, both critically and constructively, whether it be famous photographers or our fellow classmates. Additionally, beyond this, in this course, we developed a new way of looking at our surroundings and situations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became more familiar with darkroom printing techniques like dodging, burning, and contrast filters. I also learned about different photographers and became more confident in shooting portraits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned the new skill of shooting photos in black and white with film, which I have never done before.
2. Learned how to develop film and print photos in a darkroom.
3. Learned how to work with light, composition, and content to create good photos.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Susie was an excellent teacher, mentor and professional photographer who emphasized not only the technical aspects of film photography but also the aesthetic and emotional component of what made images compelling. She draws from her experiences to teach us the workflow and process of film developing, processing and printing. I enjoyed her anecdotes working for newspapers and Nat Geo as well as her one-on-one mentoring that allowed me to appreciate black-and-white as a medium of art. Susie was always willing to spend time talking about problems we were facing and devoted time for office hours to make herself as available as possible.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I think having the labs at the beginning of the semester were good to be able to learn most of the technical skills in a smaller environment given the nature of these tasks and the small spaces we needed to work in.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Susie was amazing. She once came in on a Saturday to give me her thoughts on my photos. I also loved how hands-on this class was; there was a good mix of lectures and developing/printing time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely one of the most interesting and exciting classes I've taken at Duke. Film photography and black and white is becoming harder and harder to learn in the digital age so I thought learning the tradition and technique with Susie was the best that could happen. The class, with its emphasis on technical and artistic aspects of photography, complements Susie's other classes, which focus on digital photography in documentary and storytelling settings. Susie wants to develop relationships with students and guide them along the process so although sometimes film can be overwhelming, she made it comforting and enjoyable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

2. Learning to see the logic of design as a whole system (like how an input gives an output, and how that links back to the overall functionality). We did a lot of sketching and diagramming to outline these relationships
3. Imagining more experimental/unique interfaces & thinking of unusual/new ways people can interact with a computer, such as touch, sound, motion, even things like environmental changes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The self-directed structure of the class let us explore our own interests in-depth by sticking with one project throughout the semester. I liked that we weren’t boxed into one kind of interface or topic & our presentations let each of us dive into interfaces that we were genuinely curious about. The presentation-based format also made it easy to learn from each other and see a wide range. I liked the flexible structure & think it encouraged creativity. We also kept our own "Book of Notice" throughout the semester & it was up to us what we put/how often we updated; this was also a nice way to be creative & see/be inspired by our moodboards.

To make the class even more intellectually stimulating, it could be helpful to look at a broader range of real-world experimental interfaces together as a class. While we were encouraged to explore, some of the presentations—both mine and others—started to feel a bit repetitive and leaned heavily toward apps and consumer products. Professor Seaman was also knowledgeable & knew a lot of different interfaces/works/research relevant to our presentation/project topics off the top of his head; it might have been more engaging to learn directly from some examples/insights alongside student presentations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I think this course really emphasized multiple ways of thinking, beyond just the subject matter (Tokyo) itself
1. Visual Media Analysis
- A lot of this course focused on comparing visual media sources, and understanding their implications and can be applied in a very broad context
2. Urban Studies
- This course really nailed the various factors that make up any urban environment, and how they connect (such as social, economic and political)
3. Art Historical Analysis
- We had a lot of time focused on engaging in classic art historical analysis on various materials

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Although anime is great though, I learned that there is so much more that makes the city and the country what it is. I learned so much about the history and progression of different sections in Tokyo, all the way from Shitamachi to Shibuya, and I think the class did a very good job of balancing student engagement and course work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- How Tokyo changed throughout the late 19th and 20th century from the (Edo period, Meiji restoration, wartime, etc)
- Various forms of expression that have emerged from Tokyo (fashion, art, architecture, cinema etc.)
- How to synthesize different types of media, including but not limited to movies, articles, music

Through this class I learned about screenplay formatting, the level of detail required to write a TV episode, and how to connect plot points in a sensical way.

response_text: This course taught me how to analyze film beyond the plot, focusing on visual elements like framing and color to understand deeper meanings. I also gained insight into how Chinese cinema reflects regional and historical shifts, especially through directors like Jia Zhangke. Before this class, I had no experience with film analysis, and, quite frankly, did not appreciate them to the level that I do now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the conventions of Roman drama, the various ways in which we can make deductions from historical evidence, and about the effects of Roman drama on later drama.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Reading ancient Roman scripts (tragedies, comedies, and historical drama). 
Identifying and analyzing different stock characters and their role in the plot and how they represented Roman values and perspectives. 
The interaction of politics and stage performances in ancient Rome.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: All things Roman drama. We talked about different types of plays, staging, scripts, tropes, Roman culture, politics, and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Roman tragedy, Roman comedy, and how to use different types of fragmentary evidence to make conclusions and learn about ancient Roman theater.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Examining different kinds of evidence ranging from script fragments to artistic depictions of Roman drama 
2) Considering the roles of participants, patrons, audiences, and everyone in between in regards to the integral role of drama in Roman society
3) Discovering the tropes and stories of Roman comedy, tragedy, and historical drama, and considering their impact on modern storytelling.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had reading assignments for each class, which worked well. The extra credit/make-up assignments were also excellent. The midterm and final project options were very interesting and fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the group workshops where we all would analyze different parts of a script and talk about our findings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ginsberg is awesome. Such an inspiring person to learn from, even as someone not involved in classics. Reading long articles or full scripts can be tedious, but the discussion questions always keep you thinking and challenge you to analyze the text more deeply as you read. In-class discussions are always lively and filled with fascinating details. She asks questions that would never cross your mind but make you re-evaluate how you see the Romans. I think the layout of the course is really conducive to learning, discussion, and engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked all of the plays that we read and the discussion board homework assignments on them. It was really cool to see my peers' thoughts on the readings and the discussion questions made me read more carefully. I also really liked having options for midterm and final assignments. While both options sounded interesting, I felt like I could choose the option that I felt the most confident on, which was super helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was INCREDIBLY thoughtful in its construction. Professor Ginsberg truly brought the ancient to life in the present by encouraging us to engage directly with evidence and notice patterns for ourselves. This easily could have been a boring, lecture-style class, but she invited us into the incredibly exciting world of being a Roman dramatist and made us all feel welcome in that space no matter our background. The combination of workshops, research, readings, discussions, lectures, and more created a learning environment that was vibrant and different every day.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was really neat to learn what historical evidence we have and how to interpret it!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I had no idea the role of politics in ancient roman drama and how it could be used as a vessel to safely criticize politicians.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There are so many fascinating things about Rome and Roman theater that I would never have learned without taking this course. For the first time I am thinking about the Roman Empire, as the meme goes, several times a week. Reading the actual plays and learning about the real people behind it all really puts everything into a new perspective

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: All of the small group discussion in our in class workshops was stimulating because I got to hear ideas from classmates and bounce my own ones off of them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Ginsberg's enthusiasm for the course content created an environment where everyone was encouraged to engage with the material in a really personal way. That created a collaborative, fun energy amongst the students - I felt like we all came to class every day excited to dig into new evidence.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Lauren Ginsberg is amazing and you should take the class. There are also many opportunities to make up work or get extra credit.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The scripts are so interesting! I never knew roman plays had so much drama. Plus, Professor Ginsberg IS SO PASSIONATE AND SO KNOWLEDGEABLE about this topic. It was genuinely fun to watch her lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!! Don't hesitate. I was unsure going into it. I am not a classics student, just someone with a vague interest from taking Latin. In all honesty I was just looking for a not-boring CZ credit. But this ended up being my favorite class this semester. It was interesting, engaging, a manageable work load, and I learned so much. It really rekindled my interest in Rome and was a fun refreshing part of my day.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT!!! You couldn't ask for a more exciting Area 2 Theater Studies class or CZ credit. If you think history is boring, just wait until Professor Ginsberg sweeps you up in the world of Roman drama, including everything from pranks to dragon chariots to the most insane things you could do to another person. It's awesome.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about the history of the art economy in Europe and throughout the world, applied economic knowledge to create models/projections about artists' sales, learned to write a long, in depth research paper about economic findings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Firstly, I gained a deep understanding of the evolution of art markets throughout time. In addition, I developed skills in data analysis and statistical methods through the group project. Lastly, I became more critical of widely held and broad perspectives that people hold on art markets and art auctions through the learning of survivorship bias.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the intersection of quantitative economic research and art history
2) I learned about the early rise of art markets by delving into the historical markets of Antwerp, 19th-century Paris, and Amsterdam
3) I learned about the field of cultural economics

It made me think more critically about how I use my voice online and how social media can be used not just to share my life, but to make a difference.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to distill a film from footage and audio. Especially in documentary filmmaking, constructing a narrative from piecemeal ideas is a challenge, and I developed a roadmap for this. I used to use Premier Pro but had lost almost all of my knowledge - this class was a great refresher. Camera settings and general advice for setting up impressive shots were also taught.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything I learned about film was from this class! I learned how to use Premiere Pro, I learned how to give and take critique on a film, I also learned what to look for while positioning a camera for interviews, or b-roll or anything that’s used in a film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so many things that it's hard to list all of them, especially because Professor Hareth has a way of teaching students both soft and hard skills that are helpful not only in film but in other parts of what it takes to be a successful student. For example, planning a film may seem like easy work, but it actually takes a lot of effort and practice, and you have to learn to be able to take feedback and criticism from your peers. Or, you may start filming something with a vision in mind and then realize things aren't working the way you imagined and think on the spot for ways to correct them. We also learned how to use Premiere Pro, which is much more challenging than I could have known, but without the class I wouldn't have taken the time to learn the skill, which I'm sure will be useful for my future. Lastly, we learned how to use a camera and a tripod, how to frame videos and fix lighting, how to focus on your subjects, and using various audio techniques.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how to make concepts, film these concepts, and then be in charge of the entire editing and post process
- how to successfully schedule properly and use professional equipment and software
- how to tell a story, how to convey a point, and how to beautifully execute an intention through film

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Mastering Professional Equipment
   I learned to operate the SONY A7iii and Zoom H6/H5 microphones, mastering settings like ISO, aperture, gain levels, and troubleshooting to capture high-quality visuals and audio.2. Adobe Premiere Pro Editing  
   I gained skills in editing, including color correction, audio synchronization, and applying transitions to craft polished, professional videos.3. Leveraging Camera Features* 
   I explored camera techniques like depth of field, focus, and composition to create dynamic, visually compelling shots and enhance storytelling.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the readings and movies and the class discussions we had about them. The movie screenings were really useful to engage with the material and bounce off of other peoples' ideas. The mini-reviews are interesting assignments to apply the knowledge gained over each unit.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked Coates' teaching style - some film clips, some discussion, some lecture. I really liked how we had four in-class film screening days - we watched "The Conjuring," "Star Wars," "God's Not Dead," and "Kumaré." I liked our "mini review" assignments, where you basically produce a 7-minute film review using a class reading from that specific unit and you have to argue why it should be considered religious. The movies and clips we'd watch in class were more obviously religious, so this was a chance for us to get creative and find something that seems secular and apply it to our learnings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The content in the class is really interesting and I liked the group discussions. However, this is not an "easy A" class because the TAs do all of the grading. The TAs grade super harshly and make it really hard to know how to do better in the future, which was really frustrating. Even after asking for feedback and support, they did not help us improve our grades. Also, a huge part of this grade is participation (literally speaking once per every class despite it being a large class) and the final project, which made us really nervous.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Dr. Charmaine Royal's Race, Genomics, and Society course, I developed a deeper understanding of how race, though a social construct, significantly impacts scientific research and healthcare. I learned to critically evaluate the use of racial categories in genomic studies and how they can perpetuate harmful stereotypes rather than address health disparities. The course also emphasized the importance of open communication and respectful discussion, allowing me to listen to and consider different perspectives with an open mind. Additionally, I gained insights into how race intersects with other identities, such as gender and socioeconomic status, to shape health outcomes, reinforcing the need for culturally competent care. These lessons have fostered a socially conscious and ethical approach to addressing systemic inequities in science and healthcare.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my study skills and the ability to write under pressure (during the exams). Improved collaborative skills and how to facilitate empowering and respectful discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The specific science behind why race is not biological in humans, and the history of how race developed in America, and other countries. Also learned the impact socially defined race has on perceptions and life outcomes in America and different countries, such as Brazil.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest take away from the class being that there is no biological race with the human race. The way in which we conceive race is a social construct based on a hierarchy. Humans are 99.6% genetically similar.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: participation, creative project documentary creation, and literature review

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I felt like this class was very lecture-based with not much writing, but our final project culminated in producing a documentary, which I learned useful skills from regarding collecting data, working with my discussion section/production team, and having conversations with people about very widely debated/misconceived ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about race as a social versus biological construct. Learned to think about the history of race and racism in a contextual and thorough way. Learned about genetics, intelligence and athletic ability.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel equipped with the tools and evidence to explain to others why race is not a biological concept. I have come to understand that lived experiences of individuals are shaped by genetic and environmental factors. Our final creative projects provided me with insight on how to facilitiate productive conversations about race, genomics, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This being a multidisciplinary course, we learned about many, many things. We learned the genetic basis of biological race (and the lack thereof in humans - i.e., we learned *why* humans don't have biological race); we learned about genetic ancestry, genomics, and so on; we learned about the social context of these scientific 'developments' (eugenics, profit, oppression, etc.); we learned about the fundamental theory of oppression.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the biological basis of race in humans, or lack thereof. I learned more about race, racial hierarchies, etc., in a global context. I learned about genetic testing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to separate biological and social concepts when looking at racial topics. I also understood the history behind what the modern understanding of race was. Finally, I found what it means to have different aspects of your identity and how that intersects with your biological makeup.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class provides an understanding of how scientific and genomic theories have contributed to the development of systemic racism. Discussions about historical events like Bacon's Rebellion, modern debates like race-based medicines such as BiDil, and about our understanding of race and racism and the factors informing it were incredibly engaging. The work we were doing felt important to learn about and discuss.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this class about how to work with a group, forming thoughts and structuring cohesive arguments, and the biological and social implications of race

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Charmaine Royal created an engaging and inclusive learning environment that fostered critical thinking and thoughtful discussion. Her emphasis on open dialogue encouraged students to share diverse perspectives, which enriched our understanding of complex topics related to race and genomics. One of the most impactful components of the course was the discussions where we shared our personal experiences and thoughts in a respectful, open space. These conversations allowed us to learn from one another and connect course material to real-life contexts, deepening our understanding of the social implications of genomics. The use of case studies and real-world examples also made the material more relatable and demonstrated the real-life consequences of the issues we studied. For future years, I would recommend keeping these interactive discussions, as they were instrumental in facilitating meaningful learning and fostering a supportive classroom community.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking Race, Genomics, and Society, I highly recommend it. This course offers a unique and thought-provoking perspective on how race intersects with science, especially genomics, and its implications for healthcare and society. Dr. Charmaine Royal fosters a respectful and open environment where you can engage in deep discussions, challenge assumptions, and explore the ethical dimensions of scientific research. The readings and case studies are compelling and relevant, pushing you to think critically about the role of race in shaping health outcomes and scientific practices. Additionally, the course includes distinguished guest speakers, providing valuable real-world perspectives. Be prepared to reflect, engage in meaningful conversations, and develop a more nuanced understanding of race and science. It’s a course that will not only broaden your knowledge but also inspire you to think differently about issues of social justice and equity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) THe way that types of mediums affect one another
2) how the message and the medium affect each other
3) the way multisensorial communicates affects the way we interact with everything

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close reading, analysis of social media, and production of multimodal analytical materials.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned the difference between ancient and modern ekphrasis, effective social media research tools, and how to perform a "close reading" of text and mixed media content.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned ways of approaching different mediums of content and interpreting it in different ways. For instance, how people approach the idea of protests and how the use of social media in a digitalized age changes how people consume and interact with such protests.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned close reading skills, the impact of social media on movements, and the use multisensoral in political campaigns effect the way people engage with candidates.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to close read different texts, documentaries, social media posts, political campaigns.
Understand the use of "ekphrasis"

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me several close reading strategies not only for novels but for videos, films, and social media posts that completely changed the way I interact with media outside of this class. We also covered themes of racial inequality, revolutions, politics, ekphrasis, and so much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Strategies for close reading and analysis; this was helpful for engaging in academic texts that are in the humanities, which is a bit different than what I’m used to with reading research papersRecognizing how form effected content. A big part of this course was practicing the ability to recognize the subtle and implicit ways our senses are engaged through different mediums of content and how that impacts our interpretations and understandings.We looked a lot at different protests and strategies employed. Most interesting for me was looking at Egypt and Iran during the Arab Spring which is something I haven’t read much about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked some of the group discussions, probably implement more large group discussions instead of strictly small group discussion

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our instructor did a good job of facilitating group discussions, especially when students didn't have much to say at the beginning. The course was very clearly broken down into 4 units, which also was helpful in thinking about what we were learning day-to-day and how it all fit in together.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the professor structured the course well through the required readings and reflections. There was a clear progression in the course content with lots of themes building on one another.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She was always engaging and let the students talks for the most part while also providing a healthy amount of insight for facilitating the class. She was always accommodating and understanding of every opinion, every kind of approach to certain content and never criticized any kind of response.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She had a very well constructed class layout, it was very inclusive and got everyone talking. She was also always very prepared and helped us if we were stuck on a difficult subject.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings that were assigned to be completed before every class were rarely overly long which I thought was unique, especially for Duke, and I feel like future students would appreciate that. I also enjoyed the way we viewed several videos, did presentations, and were never just being talked to.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The structure of the class was rather simple but effective. Read and reflect on content and come to class to share and develop ideas on that content. I love this format of class because it is rather free flowing and engaging. 
The parts I disliked the most were ones that stymied that format, particularly the work sheets. I feel as though giving specific content guidelines and 1 question to answer or 1 purpose in a group setting would have been just as effective and more interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the various types of readings made the course stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A lot of the material pointed to the same overall theme/message, which made the course a little bit monotonous.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because it forced me to engage and analyze different mediums of communication that I wasn't entirely familiar with beforehand. For example, for one of the assignments we were required to download TikTok and record and introduction video of ourselves. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text:
I learned and became extremely proficient in Adobe Premire.

I developed a way of thinking of seeing technology not as neutral, but shaped by and reinforcing power structures (race, gender, class, ability).

response_text: I learned how to think more broadly about media and how it relates and shapes the world of feminism. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was dynamic, inclusive, and deeply engaging. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was a great introduction into understanding film on a more technical level! We began with elements of movies like mise-en scene and cinematography and worked our way into more specific details like acting and sound design. This course has fundamentally changed the way I think about movies and made them so much more fun to watch! For example, for the film Punch Drunk Love, before this course, I would have seen it simply as a quirky and confusing romcom. However, after paying attention to things like cinematography, shot composition, the use of a telephoto lens, etc. it took on a whole new meaning and became so much more engaging to watch. Really grateful for this course helping me to put general intuition about a film into clear meaning and technical wording!One of my favorite things we learned about this semester was looking at the evolution and history of film. The course itself follows this progression in the movies we watch. It was really cool to watch clips of earlier work and inspiration for a certain film and then watch the film itself. This gave us a great perspective on where some of these creative and innovative ideas in cinema came from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the formal elements of film, such as cinematography and mise-en-scene; I also learned to think critically about sound design and the role of directors and actors; and I learned to write formal analyses of films.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze films, different things to look for when watching films, and a newfound respect for filmmaking as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The skills to identify and analyze formal elements in films, the history of film as an art and as a technology, and the production process of a film.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

How to connect texts back to a specific genre
How to analyze films in a formal way
How America's foundations are connected to the gothic/processing the past/processing traumaI'd never taken a genre english class before. I feel like my other english classes were based on one author or one time period, so this was different for me. I definitely hated classifying these texts to the gothic/horror because it felt so unnatural and pointless to me (like why do we care if this text could be said to fit into the gothic/horror space, I would rather just talk about the text itself). However, I think as we progressed throughout the class and saw the ways these genres could show up in more modern ways like with race in the bondwoman's narrative or with trauma in Get Out, I had more appreciation for this way of reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I suppose something I learned was just how much Shakespeare recycled themes and character tropes. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek does such an incredible job at facilitating open discussion - he takes everyone's points seriously and is clearly so informed/knowledgeable on these plays. Writing our gobbets (reading responses, 8 total at any point in the semester) allowed me to synthesize my thoughts across the plays and their adaptations, and they were really accessible ways with engaging closely with the week's topics. Derek really made this class so fun, and his selections of the readings/plays/films were fantastic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek made the course extremely conversational, allowing me to develop different perspectives on each text we read and movie we saw. He encouraged people to disagree with him, which left lots of room for independent analytical thought. I would keep this teaching style for future classes. Additionally, watching a variety of different Shakespeare adaptations, some strict and some loose, facilitated my understanding of what it means for a film to be an adaptation. I would continue showing films from different time periods and cultures in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought Derek found a wonderful balance between lecture and seminar, which is something I've struggled with in classes before. He always asked questions to prompt discussion, but also started each class with a 5 ish minute lecture that help put the lesson into context. I absolutely loved this course and think Derek would make a wonderful professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Witten is super interested in what he is teaching which is probably the most effective way to engage your students. I loved discussions, and it was fun to watch clips from the films. I hesitate to say I would keep the same plays in future years, because as much as I enjoyed them all, I think it would be more fun for Professor Witten to get to keep teaching new plays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like how Professor Witten kept the class very interactive and promoted collaboration among students. He was extremely energetic and excited about the material he was teaching, which made me look forward to this class every day!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I almost wish we got to start with some sort of gauge of how everyone felt about the play/film, and find points of discussion from there.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I really enjoyed this class, but it is key to make sure you manage your time well! Even though reading plays and watching films is mostly enjoyable, it is still time consuming and it might feel easy to let things fall by the wayside. It is also important to really think about your final paper throughout the semester. Because there isn't a ton of time to work on it in class, it's entirely up  to you to ensure you work on it in a timely manner while balancing your other coursework.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! Derek is incredible at making Shakespeare accessible on every level, and you'll almost certainly fall in love with these plays if you weren't already convinced of Shakespeare's storytelling abilities. Discussions were always so much fun, even just listening - the work for this class was genuinely my favorite to complete out of all of my classes. The film selections are fantastic as well as we discuss across genre and culture. There's no reason not to take this course, especially if you're an English major!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class, whether or not you love Shakespeare. Derek's insight, as well as that of your classmates, will open your mind to interesting ways of interpreting Shakespeare's material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. A better understanding of cinema as an entity through time since its conception
2. A stronger sense of what matters to filmmakers at various points in time and how that manifests in their work

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read film theory papers and understand them in regard to their historical background. I also learned how film theorist engage with one another over the years and changed ideologies with the advent of new technologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about major film theorists and their theories, including bell hooks, Bazin, Siegfried Kracauer and Erwin Panofsky. I learned how to write a paper about theory and I learned how to write and analyze films through various theoretical lenses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Overall, I gained a new understanding for how film theory has emerged and changed over time. Before, I knew film theory only from bits and pieces that I had read (out of context) in other courses, but this course really helped to frame and contextualize theory as a whole. I most enjoyed the semiotics unit and how investigating cinema as a language influenced more modern theorists in thinking about the socio-political impacts of film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned some historical background on cinema and early film, as well as more applied techniques like understanding film production/construction of shots/the effect they have and how to critically evaluate the position a film might have relative to its social/political context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: From classical film theory to modern and contemporary film theory. Learned how to read theories and analyze films with the theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history and ideologies surrounding specific figures who have contributed to the development of film theory. I feel that my understanding of realism and identity as it relates to cinema strengthened after contextualizing films with in-class lectures. Finally, I had the opportunity to expand upon and adapt a paper to fit new criteria. I appreciated the space to rework and build a paper after the feedback stage as I often abandon papers once they are submitted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

The professor also provided many contexts that made the theories make more sense. The films we watched were all really great and the professor was good at guiding us on how to analyze films shot to shot and connected them with the theories. So I really learned a lot about how to watch a film critically.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Often times the class stayed silent or surface-level when asked questions related to the readings or films. I feel that either making the class entirely lecture-based or cultivating an environment that inspires participation would enhance intellectual simulation. Because the readings were dense, I feel that assigning smaller sections would increase students engagement and understanding with them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this media theory course, I gained a deep understanding of media's evolution, from foundational debates about writing and mediation to contemporary digital culture. The course equipped me with critical frameworks to analyze how different media forms - from print to digital platforms - shape human experience and social relationships. Key theoretical concepts like technological determinism, cultural techniques, and media archaeology enhanced my ability to examine the complex interplay between media, technology, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a new perspective on what the "media" term media can mean, gained new frameworks to understanding how society and media interact, and gained meaningful insight into how I personally interact with media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has given me a whole new understanding of the concept of media. Because before I chose this major, I knew almost nothing about media. In this class, I learned a lot about the concept of media and the historical process of media. In particular, I am deeply impressed by McLuhan's theory. He taught me that media can influence our perception and shape our society. And I also realized commodification and entertainment, it makes me know that we need to keep our own judgment in the market to find the real value

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: This was my first experience doing historical analysis. I learned how to look at historical artifacts, art, and architecture and connect it to the broader social and political environment of the time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. describing complex events in simpler words: for our article summaries, we were told to write in simpler terms, a skill which I had not practiced before the class.
2. date memorization: I learned a couple tricks for memorizing dates that greatly benefited me on the tests.
3. reading large amounts of text at a time: I further developed my annotation and skimming skills in this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

-analyzing historical sources
