question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A variety of Roman Spectacles throughout different periods of the the Roman Republic. Reading primary sources, summarizing complex academic articles, memorizing and synthesizing artistic and historical effects to answer broad questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the Roman Empire -- I started from a very basic understanding of the Roman Empire and gained a vast breadth of knowledge on Roman culture and society. Outside of historical knowledge I was able to understand the mind of the average Roman during this period–why they enjoyed and participated in such violent activities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was less method based, and more of a knowledge dump. We learned about the evolution of Roman spectacles over the course of the Republican and Imperial periods, analyzing the historical, social, psychological, and political reasons they were enacted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about Roman history and why the Romans were so enraptured in spectacle. 
I learned that there was a lot of influence of Greek culture 
I learned that the modern world could be comparable to the Romans

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about why the Ancient Romans had the spectacles they had such as the gladiator fights, beast hunts, and chariot races. Even though gladiator fights are probably the most well-known widely, especially as brutally violent, almost sadistic spectacles, they had a greater purpose in Roman society at the time. I also learned that there was a time when the Romans did not build permanent spectacle buildings but rather built temporary ones but with good reason. I have developed a better understanding of this ancient civilization in particular and this has also allowed me to be more open-minded when it comes to thinking out other cultures or civilizations doing things that may seem odd to us but make a lot of sense when you see it from their perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to shoot with a Bolex camera and load 16mm film. I learned how to develop film in the darkroom with chemicals. I also learned some techniques to create in-camera special effects while shooting my film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned specific techniques related to analog filmmaking. Specific takeaways include darkroom processing of Soundstock, loading and shooting 16mm film on a Bolex camera, and basic lighting setups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how film works (how photos are actually created), the history of it, of course 16 mm film, how to use a Bolex camera, and how to use Premier Pro for editing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How film works. How to do direct animation. How to edit the film with Steenbeck. How to load, and shoot with Bolex 16. How to develop Soundstock and TriX.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was very helpful in developing technical skills related to filmmaking, editing, film processing, and shooting. Working in the darkroom was a very informative hands-on experience, as was using the Steenbeck manual editing table to splice and cut together films physically. In addition to the Steenbeck editing techniques, we were taught how to use Adobe Lightroom to edit our films digitally. I also got comfortable using the Bolex camera while making films for the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the flow and structure of the course -- no edits.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Madison allowed for us to be hands on throughout the film process, and learn through shooting and practicing how to load film. I enjoyed learning how to do these things in class and then practicing outside.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Overall, this was my favorite course of the semester due to the positive learning environment of the class. Not only did Madison facilitate our learning through encouraging instruction and patience, but a kind and thoughtful class community was fostered through constructive critique days and collaborative--but low pressure--group projects. Overall, I looked forward to coming to class every week and learning alongside everyone.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The layout is good. Start with the theory part and then transfer to film, the camera last.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hill provided a good balance of lecturing (on the history, theory, technology, etc. of filmmaking) and practical application of the concepts we learned in class. I appreciated this structure and always felt I had a strong informational basis before going out and practicing filmmaking techniques myself. Each class session felt like a constructive progression from the previous one. I think the syllabus was laid out nicely as it allowed for a smooth transition between topics and reflected our growing experience over the course of the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: in class shooting and hands on exercises

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I also liked the in class shooting exercises because they had us working together to practice shooting techniques. Outside of class, I wasn’t as willing to experiment with techniques because I was worried about messing up my film.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found this course stimulating due to the medium itself. I loved working with 16mm film and using it to explore my ideas in creative new ways. I also found the assignments themselves (direct animation, found footage, cinepoem, and the final project) to be interesting and unique, allowing me the chance to experiment with techniques in new ways for each assignment. I particularly enjoyed the direct animation and cinepoem projects.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I didn't know anything about film before and I learned so much about how to handle, develop, and edit film - so it was such a great learning experience.  This is more of a personal interest, but I would love to learn more about the history and iconic films that changed the film industry.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The reading is somehow disregarded by the class. If we could have simplified them and discussed them in class it would have been more helpful to understand the film, bolex and overall filmmaking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the course stimulating first by nature of the subject, as 16mm analog filmmaking is a topic of interest to me and one with which I had no prior experience. I think the readings, projects, and exercises chosen for this iteration of the course were also particularly interesting. Madison's instruction was consistently engaging and informative.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a fun intro level course to 16mm film! If you want time to do some hands on art, this is the place. Shooting and developing can be a little stressful, but Madison was always very responsive and helpful when reached out to. Make sure you take notes in class to prepare for shooting, and start your projects far before they are due.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course! Madison is a wonderful instructor who will introduce you to the joys and intricacies of analog filmmaking. Although analog can be frustrating at times, this course allows you to experience both the excitement of getting it right (film turning out as intended) and the mistakes that are inherent to 16mm filmmaking, without the stress of having to be the perfect filmmaker. Instead, grace is given for all students to learn the medium and experiment with their own creative impulses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is what you make it - you can really learn a lot if you do the readings, participate, and are intentional about your film - and it's really fun!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would suggest this course to anyone interested or excited about filmmaking, whether analog or digital. The 16mm process is challenging but rewarding, and a good way to explore both practical and creative skills.

I don't know if cold-calling would have helped me engage more, but I did really appreciate the presentations on an assigned reading that the class did at one point in the semester- it forced me to speak and otherwise engage when I likely would have remained silent in a discussion. Some sort of... incentivized, maayybe required projects or other form of participation in-class would maybe help?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A course that encompasses a breadth of material to critically interrogate what constitutes "story" and to whom. I learned about Eastern vs. Western storytelling modalities and the role of Orientalism in framing narratives in faraway lands through our unit on A Thousand and One Nights, as well as questioning if it is possible, in the guise of the modern novel with its emphasis on human consumption and emotion, to tell a story with a non-human subject by exploring the place of Sun Wu Kong in the Chinese literary canon. Turning our attention to familiar European storytelling traditions, we also studied the morphology of fairytales, as explicated by Vladimir Propp, and the socio-psychological imperatives baked into the archetypes of "fairy stories," as posited by Tolkien. We likewise explored the ways the framework of game changes narratives structures by imposing ludology, rather than temporality, to guide stories.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The central component of this class is to write nine essays centered around a storyworld of your choosing, fleshing out various aspects of the world to understand the cogs that make the machine of story function. These essays are a joy to write, as they are fueled by student interest, and they are also an essential tool for learning to apply the various methodologies and modalities gone over in lecture. Having these available as an open forum for everyone to look at each other's work promoted student engagement in our own storyworlds as well as close-readings of our peers, since we could comment and generate dialogue on each other's posts. Furthermore, class featured a mix of lecture and seminar-style engagement, which enabled us to wrangle with concepts for ourselves and develop our own nuanced opinions on how the art of worldbuilding and the various cultural heritages it draws upon can be done.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I enjoyed following along storyworlds familiar and new through the eyes of my peers and their analyses of what makes these worlds shine or fall flat. I immensely enjoyed lecture and the various scratchpad exercises (tell a story in 6 words, craft a mystery, map archetypes to a fairytale, "Are all stories bound up in power, property, and domination?" etc). done with my peers. These encouraged us to debate the elements of story and form our own opinions on how we form and digest narratives. Dr. Chow's warm demeanor and razor-sharp intellect transform this class from an academic exercise to a veritable intellectual family.

response_text: I honed the skill of delving into unfamiliar topics, conducting thorough research, and crafting compelling stories based on them. The course consistently challenged us to write scripts on subjects we had no personal experience with or prior knowledge of. I gained proficiency in gathering both primary and secondary resources, covering historical contexts, technical details, and cultural backgrounds.Additionally, I mastered the art of writing within tight deadlines. With a weekly writing assignment, I learned to draft quickly and then focus on revisions rather than getting bogged down by details in the initial draft.Lastly, I cultivated the ability to provide constructive feedback to my peers in class. Engaging in script readings and discussions allowed me to refine my communication and comprehension skills while collaborating effectively with my classmates.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this class. You will have the time of your life in Venice and really get to feel like a local in Italy. It is so rewarding to recognize the routes and buildings in Venice, the more you explore. The class is taught by the most wonderful Professor and TA, and they really support you in everything. The content is also very interesting and diverse.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this course to any and every student. If someone has even a small interest in art, history, and politics, this class is perfect. Living in Venice is incredible, and I have never been in a more immersive class in terms of actively experiencing the artworks which we learn about every day. The workload is not prohibitive in the slightest, and it honestly creates a good balance to have some structure in day-to-day life while living in Venice. The course is so interesting, and I have seen more beautiful things while on this program than I could possibly recall. Both Professor Rogerson and Mitch Moste are incredible people and teachers who made this course fun and welcoming and made a foreign city feel safe and easy to navigate.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely try to be very open minded, commit to all the new experiences you are about to have, and have fun of course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

It also pushed my understanding of art as a political force, revealing how unique ideas can have great impacts on policy change and societal expectations.

response_text: This course traced shifts in Japanese history and culture through art, with a specific focus on prints. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Milligan was one of the most helpful and knowledgeable professors I’ve had at my time at Duke- and I’m a BME major. He had a very clear and detailed lesson plan that got introductory filmmakers caught up with the more advanced students in the class, and even offered workshops on various things like lighting, camera work, and editing throughout the year to bolster our learning. I think it was so cool we were able to use the film studio for every class, as instead of just watching and discussing film pieces we were able to create and learn as we made film together.

response_text: The instructor is super encouraging and great at sharing his vast knowledge with students. He is a good teacher and can easily explain concepts and techniques to a beginner filmmaker. I also think other short assignments are great in the way they focus on one particular skill of filmmaking. This allows students to really master a skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got a lot better at my craft. Getting to practice it for a whole semester, following my own methodology, is amazing and such a privilege!I learned how to present my progress. Progress comes in all forms, and sometimes it isn't as tangible or immediately noticeable so it must be communicated verbally instead. But this communication, whether it is in the form of a Powerpoint or spoken word, is important so that the class can give good feedback and my involvement is still evident.I learned how to plan a semester-long project from start to finish. I've never done something like this before because the longest project I've ever completed was about half a semester long, with pre-made guidelines. Writing my own syllabus was a new exercise for me. I also learned how to set goals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think the skill I most developed over the course of this semester was self-discipline. In creating my short film, I really had to organize my time effectively and motivate myself to keep on track, and I felt like this course helped us structure the development of this skill well. I also learned a lot about the process of production and all the little administrative tasks that go into making a film. Finally, I got better at presenting unfinished works in front of people. Normally, in the past, I would only ever show finished works. However, to receive valuable feedback, I have realized that showing progress to people along the way is really important.

response_text: I think this course is very effective in drawing conenctions between various different fields of research. I commonly found myself presenting on topics that I found interesting, and both the professor and my colleagues would recommend me new topics to explore. The course also gives the students a lot of freedom in the topics they explore, so I was able to learn a lot of knowledge around topics that I wouldn't think of researching myself, but find interesting as they pertain to the body as an electrochemical computer. The three things I learned then are the ability to make connections between topics, the importance of ethics in artificial intelligence, and being able to think of humans from an artificial intelligence's point of view.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The current discussion and relevance of Ecomedia. It helped me expand my conception of media and its relationship with the environment and ecological issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better theoretical understanding of eco-media as a scholarly field, I had access to a summary of discussions concerning Ecology in the Humanities (such as the Anthropocene and derived concepts), I had access to case studies of art and media related to Ecological discussions, especially in China.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Very interesting articles, learned a lot from these readings. For example, "bare life", "power relationship".
The professor offers many profound films that discuss ecological issues in society. Analyze and discuss these movies in conjunction with reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I first learned what eco-media is, and what topics and methods eco-media covers. Secondly, I learned how to analyze scenes in a film that a director might be inclined to express. Third, I learned a conceptual framework from academic film reviews that can provide a deeper perspective for interpreting films related to environmental issues, such as global waste, mining industries, toxicity, manufactured landscape, and multispecies entanglement.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how different groups of people embrace eco-media as an approach to environmental criticism. Most importantly, I learned how varied directors portrayed manifestations of environmental degradation differently to approach the questions concerning agency and subalternity. 
2. I learned methods of analyzing not only eco-media works but also its materiality. Specifically, I learned about how they are produced, circulated and consumed. More importantly, I learned how the production and circulation of media could impose secondary toxic effects on the environment.
3. The course content also helps me to learn to situate and historicize different forms of precarity regarding one's embeddedness within global capitalism.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I believe the course could have been more intellectually stimulating with greater direct engagement from the professor through lectures or guided presentations. The professor clearly has deep knowledge of the subject, but I often felt there were limited opportunities to learn directly from his expertise. The course leaned heavily on student presentations, which at times led to uneven coverage of the material. Based on my experience in other seminars, dividing class time more evenly—half instructor-led and half student-led—has proven to be a more effective and enriching structure. This approach provides a stronger foundation for discussion and fosters a more consistent and engaging learning experience.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
-The Second Nature experience and review was a highlight of the semester for me. Having an outside of class activity to apply our knowledge to was very useful and fun. It could be nice to do something like that all together as a class. 
-The object lessons were stimulating at the beginning of the semester and then became a bit redundant. If there was some sort of a shift in direction with the object lessons about halfway through the semester, it could make students more engaged with them. This could be suggesting a theme to pull an object from, or connecting readings to an object that was already posted about, etc.
-Having explicit space to discuss object lessons in class would have been helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course was very enriching and allowed me to develop several important skills and insights: 
1) Exploration of Austrian Postwar Literature and Film: I gained a deep understanding of four major Austrian writers and filmmakers—Thomas Bernhard, Elfriede Jelinek, Michael Haneke, and Ulrich Seidl—whose works are foundational to postwar cultural and literary criticism in Austria.
2) Close Reading and Film Analysis: I improved my ability to engage in close reading and film analysis, emphasizing how to critically unpack texts and visual narratives in relation to broader social and cultural contexts.
3) Understanding Representations of Violence: I explored how graphic depictions of violence can serve as tools for education and enlightenment, pushing myself to remain open-minded about the purpose and impact of such representations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained exposure to a variety of Austrian films that I might not have encountered otherwise, broadening my understanding of Austrian film culture and its unique themes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was highly interested in breaking down the notion of a Eurocentric Humanistic ideal due to the nature of the course design, i.e. transgressive thinkers. However, I learnt that often in academia, one has to bite the bullet and decide what battles to fight. As such I learnt to disengage from arguments that did not give me back fruitful ideas and were unproductive to thinking critically about the issues the artists' work that was the primary material in the course was trying to do. The actual work was often buried in the discussions about the artists themselves and the participants were not asked to refrain from make universal statements about the literary or film-studies based values expressed in the works. I learnt that when the discussion becomes performative, I must quietly save my labor for when I have the intellectual and emotional energy. I enjoyed quite a few of the readings, both primary and secondary, but found that the discussions were often overshadowed by manspreading in the workplace, an issue often unaddressed in the graduate seminar, a workspace often disguised as solely a classroom. Lastly, and on a positive note, I learnt how to identify textual evidence to dialectically decipher the place a given text occupies in the literary history as visible from the contemporary moment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learnt how to theorize my interpretation of a text based on a close reading instead of using theoretical lenses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close readings, discourse on humanism in pre-war Austria, and film/image analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely got better at close readings!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was particularly beneficial in providing opportunities to practice close reading via discussion posts. The course helped me develop a stronger understanding of literary studies as a discipline, including its language. It finally aided in developing my understanding and deployment of form to buttress close readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment was positive, and the course structure effectively supported my learning:* Student-Led Discussions: I appreciated the collaborative approach, as students leading parts of the discussion fostered engagement and new perspectives.
* Weekly Discussion Posts: Writing weekly posts allowed me to engage deeply with the materials, and I appreciated that the instructor thoughtfully read and provided feedback on all posts.
* Instructor Engagement: The instructor created an encouraging atmosphere for intellectual exploration.However, I think the discussions could benefit from integrating the weekly posts more directly into the class conversations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment, I appreciated the instructor's openness and flexibility, which created a welcoming space for discussion. The weekly Canvas responses were particularly effective in fostering engagement and reflection, and I think this component should be kept for future classes. However, I would suggest incorporating more structured guidance from the instructor, as well as adding theoretical background and close readings to provide a stronger foundation for analyzing the films. These additions would enhance the learning experience by balancing discussion with deeper context and analysis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professsor-instructor was highly amenable to being flexible about the primary textual materials under study in this class, especially with regard to the sensitivity of some participants and an incident that left many shook beyond performative solidarity with a participant new to the program. Moreover, the professor-instructor was kind about my own medical condition related to psychiatric health and did not hold it against me when I had to retreat from energetic participation into passive note-taking mode. I did not feel pressure to partake in any opinion-based consensus creation when the loudest members of the seminar were doing their usual think-out-loud discussions. I think the best part of this course was the discussion posts where the value-systems of each participants may be seen through close analysis of their writing styles and philosophical standpoints.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was intellectually engaging, but there is room for improvement in the selection of secondary readings: Some texts were excellent (I particularly enjoyed the Rita Felski reading), but others were less effective due to unclear writing or arguments (e.g., Ahmed, Berlant, Nelson). The syllabus could have included foundational texts like Susan Sontag’s "On Photography" and "Looking at War," which were mentioned in class but not assigned. These could have enriched our discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class stimulating was the exposure to a range of Austrian films that I wouldn’t have encountered otherwise. However, it could have been more intellectually stimulating with a stronger theoretical foundation and more guided analysis. Incorporating close readings of the texts, deeper engagement with key concepts, and connecting these ideas more explicitly to the films would have enhanced the intellectual depth. Additionally, balancing open discussions with structured input from the instructor could make the class more engaging and thought-provoking. One area for improvement would be including more trigger warnings and regularly checking in on students' mental health, as the nature of the films often addressed challenging and sensitive topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: If the women were encouraged to speak more by asking the men to pipe down sometimes. I would have loved to see more decolonial thought on humanism as an exclusionary method to control humans and their poetic abilities as a member of the planet on a continuum with other forms of life and the material world that sustains them, rather than the notion of humans as elevated beings in control over the material reality upon which they are parasitic. far from being nihilistic, this poetic idea of a human as creative and trangressive rather than ascriptive and normative could have been the impetus for more stimulating and self-degrandizing set of discussions rather than 'redemption' as the limit of thought in the secularized versions of a Euro-Christian humanism.

response_text:
The structure of the class was rather simple but effective. Read and reflect on content and come to class to share and develop ideas on that content. I love this format of class because it is rather free flowing and engaging. 
The parts I disliked the most were ones that stymied that format, particularly the work sheets. I feel as though giving specific content guidelines and 1 question to answer or 1 purpose in a group setting would have been just as effective and more interesting.
